Hi guys - great group!

I've searched the group in case these questions hav=
e already been answered - apologies if I missed them!

I have added my own =
implementation of NEAT to my AL framework (I'm a hobbyist) - like most peop=
le who implement their own I've done this so I can fully understand the alg=
orithm.

I've read Ken's paper, stepped through the original code and also =
read the chapter in AI Techniques for Game Programming along with other art=
icles/blogs etc.  My implementation seems to run pretty well - although I h=
aven't compared it's performance (in terms of efficiency at finding solutio=
ns) to any other implementations.

Although I treat both Node Genes and Con=
nection Genes as innovations for completeness - the system doesn't make use=
 of the innovation IDs for nodes - as to me an innovation resulting from a =
new node is the associated connection innovations created.  Something makes=
 me think this may be a mistake and I'm missing something.  However a Conne=
ction is defined by the two nodes it connects - and a Node is defined by it=
's position in a 0-1 x 0-1 2d space.  This means that nodes are considered =
the same if they occupy the same space (x,y) - there is no concept of a uni=
que NodeID.  When a Node is created during a mutation it is given the X,Y p=
osition half way between nodes defining the connection it is splitting.  It=
 is possible that in the future I will add other attributes to Nodes which =
will be taken into account for Node equality too - but for now it is just X=
,Y.

So I have two questions:

1)  When a Connection is disabled and then r=
e-enabled in the future from crossover - if this connection is subsequently=
 split again by a new node mutation - my implementation effectively looses =
this mutation because the new node and connections have already been added =
to the genotype in the original mutation.  So all that happens is the conne=
ction is disabled - again.  Mat's book mentions this and implies that a new=
 innovation should be created - which i guess means the network ends up wit=
h an additional node?  I couldn't see where this explicitly happened in Ken=
's code.

2) Is the approach of defining a node by its position flawed? 


=
Thanks for your help

cheers
Phill
